climbs.name: You Ain't Nothin But a Hang Dog

content.description:
Excellent climb! Fluid moves, with just a little spice. 

 Climb the interesting holds near the right arete of the block. Can be tricky in the middle and at the very top.
content.protection: Top Rope. There are no anchors, so one will have to be made from above. Bring long lengths of static lines (50').EDIT!: As of 5/7/20, the ETCC bolted this route. The anchor remains accessible to toprope. Climbed as a sport route, it is 5 bolts to anchors.
content.location: Right side of the Elvis area block.

content.description: Sit start at the lip of the low roof on obvious holds.  Make big moves straight up and top out.
First move crux. Climb over the opening bulge then hang on to excellent iron band pockets to the top. Stick Clip.
content.location: After descending the stairs, take an immediate right. This climb is on the face just around the corner.

content.description: Establish yourself in the wide crack feature, then make your way up and onto the face until you reach the roof. Pull the roof on wonderful jugs to the top.
content.protection: 4 glue-ins to anchors. Stick clip the first bolt.
content.location: The same cliffline as the Elvis Wall but just to the climber's right.

climbs.name: Rock and Roll Will Never Die

content.description: Crux move off the ground. Climb the water gunnel feature on toothy rock. Plenty of interesting holds, with a little spice. Stick clip.
content.location: Climber's right of the Elvis Wall. An obvious water line just before the cliff breaks down.

content.description: Sit Start in a low juggy hole.  Follow the lip and top out staying off the lower rail
content.location: Follow the lower trail approx. .5 mile and follow a faint schwack to the left after passing the cluster of boulders.   35.865670, -84.893110

content.description: Obvious water groove. Straight forward climbing.
content.protection: Top Rope. There are no anchors, so one will have to be made from above. Bring long lengths of static lines (50').
content.location: Find the pyramid spray paint tag and it is just to the left.  When you decend the stairs from the top, exit the rock ally, then turn and look left and walk perhaps 25'.

content.description: Straightforward, climb the slabby arete.
content.location: Follow the lower trail past the first reroute.  This will be the first boulder you see on the left side of the trail.   35.866151, -84.890909

content.description: Straight forward climbing to the top.  Crux is at the lip midway, pull through to easy pockets and pinches above.
content.protection: This was rebolted by the ETCC in the spring of 2020. It is now 5 bolts to anchors.

content.description: Follow the lower rail around the arete and top out in large jugs above the left face.
Begin the thin face on a couple good holds, then move through a surprisingly thin section to the roof. Pull the roof on horizontals, then establish on the face above to the top.
content.protection: Top rope anchors have been installed. No bolts for now.
content.location: 8 feet to the climber's right from the base of "Elvis Love Child."

content.description:
Thin nearly vertical face climb.  Climb the slopes and dishes and make the feet stick until you hit the rest, then power through the second half to a horizontal, then top out.  

  This was one of the routes which was bolted and then chopped. It appears someone put a new bolt in, then removed the hanger leaving a bright shiny stud about midway.
content.protection: Top Rope. There are no anchors, so one will have to be made from above. Bring long lengths of static lines (50').
content.location: Walk down the stairs from the tower. On your left just before you exit the rock alley, this climbs the face just to the left of the arete.  Obvious green graffiti at the base.

content.description: Get the opening jug and the long sidepull, then work your way up through fun feet and some bizarre micro chickenheads to the top.
content.protection: Single rack to #1/#2. Top has bolted anchors accessible from the top for group top ropes.
content.location: Far right arete of the Flyin' Hawaiian Wall.

content.description: Start on the right side of the faint corner in the middle of the boulder.  Traverse right all the way to the finish of Chianti.
content.location: After descending the steps through the slot, go straight about 100ft.  This is the steep 45 degree overhanging boulder on your right.35.866757, -84.895580

content.description: Thin and sustained, albeit short, this route is excellent quality but has grown over some since the hey day of Black Mountain.  The bolts were chopped and the studs are still visible.  Might want to bring a brush, but worth a little effort.
content.protection: Top Rope. There are no anchors, so one will have to be made from above. Bring long lengths of static lines (50').
content.location: Just behind the Candy Crack Block and just to the right of a tree.  The gully scramble people used to climb out is about 10' to the left. However, it is not far to use the stairs. Difficult to describe without a map.

content.description: Fun climb. Just to the right of the arete.
content.protection: Top Rope. There are no bolts, so use the anchors for "Elvis Never Wore Lycra" to climb this arete. Bring long lengths of static lines if making an anchor from above (50').
content.location: Elvis Area. The first of three climbs to the right of the psudo-piller climb Love and Abuse.

content.description: Difficult start. Get the jug rail after an odd move off the ground, then head for the obvious knob and rest, then straight up to the top.
content.protection:
Top Rope. There are no anchors, so one will have to be made from above. Bring long lengths of static lines (50').

 EDIT!: As of 5/7/20, the ETCC bolted this route. Climbed as a sport route, it is 4 bolts to anchors.

content.description: Fun climbing on bomber flakes.  Well worth the time!
content.protection: EDIT!: As of 5/7/20, the ETCC bolted this route. The top remains accessible to toprope, as the top anchors are in reach of the top. Climbed as a sport route, it is 4 bolts to anchors.
content.location: Just around the arete from the other three Elvis climbs. A large crack between boulders is to climbers right when standing at the base of the climb.

content.description:
Good holds all the way up, although slightly sandy and pebbly.

 If this has already been done before, please post the previous route info so I can update it.
content.location:
First boulder that is encountered when you take the low trail.

 35.867092,-84.890296

content.description: Sit start in obvious flake near the right side of the overhanging face.  Work up and right to the arete, then up to finish on the obvious jug.
content.location: After descending the steps through the slot, go straight about 100ft.  This is the steep 45 degree overhanging boulder on your right.35.866757, -84.895580

content.description: This area has a high collection of moderates and toprope routes. The Flyin' Hawaiian wall and the Elvis Wall are both in this Upper Area.
